message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin that can be used at mealtimes to control blood sugar spikes. NPH insulin and regular insulin have slower onset times and are used for longer-term control. Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin that provides basal insulin coverage over 24 hours but is not appropriate for use at mealtimes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin analog that can be used during mealtimes. NPH and regular insulin require longer onset and duration of action, and insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin that cannot be used for rapid action during meals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin analog that is useful for rapid action during mealtimes. NPH insulin and insulin glargine are intermediate- and long-acting insulins, respectively, and are not appropriate for rapid action. A combination of NPH and regular insulin can be used, but insulin lispro is a more convenient option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin analog that can be used during mealtimes to control blood sugar levels in patients with type 1 diabetes. NPH insulin is intermediate-acting and not appropriate for use during mealtimes. Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analog and not appropriate for rapid action during mealtimes. NPH and regular insulin combination also have slower onset and peak times compared to insulin lispro.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin used to control blood sugar levels during mealtimes. NPH insulin and insulin glargine are long-acting insulins used to maintain baseline blood sugar levels, and regular insulin is a short-acting insulin typically used for correction doses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro has a rapid onset of action and is ideal for mealtimes. NPH insulin and insulin glargine have slower onsets of action and are used for basal insulin. NPH and regular insulin are both intermediate-acting insulins and are not ideal for rapid action during mealtimes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin that is commonly used during mealtimes to control blood sugar levels. NPH insulin and regular insulin are not rapid-acting, and insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin that is used for basal insulin coverage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin, which can be used during mealtimes to control blood sugar levels in patients with type 1 diabetes. NPH insulin and insulin glargine are both long-acting insulins and regular insulin is a short-acting insulin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin that can be used to manage blood glucose spikes during mealtimes. NPH insulin is intermediate-acting and regular insulin is short-acting, so they would not be the optimal choices for this purpose. Insulin glargine is long-acting and used for basal insulin coverage, not for rapid action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin that starts to work within 15 minutes after injection, peaks in 1 hour, and lasts for 2 to 4 hours. This is the best option for quick-acting insulin required during mealtimes for a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis. NPH insulin and insulin glargine are long-acting insulins and NPH and regular insulin is a combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulins.
